Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mothership/Daughtership Architectures for In Situ Science by Robotic Sensor Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop fundamental understanding of control strategies that can exploit the complimentary computation, sensing, and communication capabilities of the members of a mothership/daughtership robotic sensor network performing in situ volumetric sensing. Concepts from networked unmanned systems, cooperative control, controlled mobility in ad hoc networks, motion planning, and optimal distributed sensing are combined to create a new heterogeneous robot team comprised of two classes of robots with significantly different, though complementary, attributes. Research activities are organized into three main thrusts: i.) daughtership control using ordered upwind methods for motion planning in the presence of strong currents and decentralized coverage control for cooperative sampling in the presence of intermittent communication; ii.) mothership control algorithms based on reinforcement learning to provide delay-tolerant networking and stochastic dynamic programming for optimal deployment and reassignment of the daughterships; and iii.) experimental demonstration performed on an indoor robotic sensor network, outdoors on a heterogeneous unmanned aircraft system, and part of field campaigns with atmospheric scientists.

The proposed research project will provide new capabilities for in situ volumetric sampling of complex atmospheric phenomena which will lead to a direct improvement in the ability to understand complex environments. This project will have its broadest impact through the applications that will benefit from robotic sensor networks performing in situ science. Collaborations focus on the study of tornadogenesis in severe storms, sea ice change, and spatio-temporal evolution of airmass boundaries. Additionally, research and education are integrated into activities aimed at improving the perception of the engineering field by K-12 students, retaining those students who are initially attracted to engineering, bringing hands-on active learning to several aerial robotic courses, and fostering interaction between scientists and engineering researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcome of this project was the design, implementation, and field deployment of an autonomous unmanned aircraft system for performing volumetric sensing in complex atmospheric phenomena. The project combined elements of robotics, control theory, unmanned systems, embedded systems, and networked communication. Research and education activities were embedded into a set of collaborations with atmospheric scientists, research centers, and unmanned systems developers in order to ensure the consideration of realistic application scenarios and to facilitate dissemination and technology transfer of the proposed work.

 

Algorithms and techniques developed in this project were deployed on the Tempest unmanned aircraft system as part of the Second Verification of Rotation in Tornadoes Experiment (VORTEX2). Those techniques helped enable the first-ever sampling of a tornadic supercell thunderstorm by an unmanned aircraft system. Follow-on work has also enabled cooperative environmental sampling by teams of unmanned aircraft and the first coordinated sampling of the outflow boundary of a severe thunderstorm.

 

The technical outcomes of the project are planning and control algorithms that can exploit the computation, sensing, and communication capabilities of robotic sensor network performing in situ volumetric sensing. Algorithms were created for online, dynamic motion planning in the presence of strong currents or winds. These algorithms were designed to work with wind data presented on a grid, e.g. from a numerical weather prediction, and can be updated quickly in response to changes in the world.

 

Broader impacts of the project are twofold. First, unmanned aircraft systems provide a novel capability to produce measurements that cannot be obtained with existing systems. The collection of in situ data over large spatial and temporal scales in hostile locations will lead to a direct improvement in the ability to model and understand complex environments, and will in turn lead to systems better able to save lives. Relevant applications include the study of severe storm formation for improved warning systems and monitoring Polar sea ice as a bellwether for global climate change. Continued collaboration with atmospheric scientists will facilitate dissemination of these concepts on fielded systems.

 

The second broader impact relates to the integration of research material into course curriculum and student projects. Several undergraduate and graduate students participated directly in the field experiments in support of this project. Research results were incorporated into several courses in the Department of Aerospace Engineering Sciences at the University of Colorado, including the junior-level Aircraft Dynamics course, the introductory graduate-level Automatic Control Theory course, and the advanced graduate level Small Unmanned Aircraft Guidance and Control course.
